items.title: England 2023 - Day 8
items.summary: This morning a taxi picked us up at 9:30 to take us to the start of our walk in Abbotsbury. From there we hiked towards the sea with views of the Fleet Lagoon. A sand bar cuts off this large area from the rest of…
items.content_html:
This morning a taxi picked us up at 9:30 to take us to the start of our walk in Abbotsbury.  From there we hiked towards the sea with views of the Fleet Lagoon.  A sand bar cuts off this large area from the rest of the sea.  

We saw a couple of pillboxes - these were WW2 fortifications built to defend against the pending German invasion.

From there we had a very steep climb up to St. Catherine's Chapel.  It was likely built in the 14th century by the monks of the abbey in Abbotsford as a place of pilgrimage.  It was also used as a beacon for passing ships and and a light was kept burning at the top of the stair turret.  Inside there are little nooks in the wall where people have left notes.

We headed down the hill into Abbotsbury - below is what remains of the abbey....

and had lunch at the Old School Tearooms...

Some locals were playing dominos at the table next to us...

From there we climbed to the top of the ridge that follows the coast line.  There are several burial mounds there dating back 4000 years ago.

The views of the coast were amazing...and you can still see St. Catherine's Chapel!

We carried on along the ridge to the Trig point - technically a Triangulation Station.  These were fixed landmarks installed years ago to help with surveying and mapping.

From here we headed down into the village of Puncknowle and to the Crown Pub for a break.

Finally, the last leg of the trip took us back to the coast and along the South West Coast Path - England's longest national trail at 630 miles.  We were very happy to see our hotel ahead.  Today was our last and our longest walk at 11 miles. 

Tomorrow we take the train from Dorchester back to London.

items.title: England 2023 - Day 7
items.summary: We headed out from Bridport around 10 am this morning and walked to the village of Walditch. As usual, a series of fields, lanes, paths to get there. We hiked up to a lookout area where you can see the town of West Bay and…
items.content_html:
We headed out from Bridport around 10 am this morning and walked to the village of Walditch.  As usual, a series of fields, lanes, paths to get there.

We hiked up to a lookout area where you can see the town of West Bay and the sea beyond.  It was a beautiful clear day with lots of sunshine. We've been blessed with great weather - generally getting to a high of around 20 degrees or so - perfect weather for walking.

We stopped by three different churches including this one below located beside an apple orchard.  One of the churches had a service underway, so we sat and listened.  There were about eight parishoners there, including the organist.  It's not hard to see why the Church of England has to be supported financially by the government to survive.  However the folks there were very friendly and seemed to appreciate us visiting.

We stopped at the New Inn at Shipton Gorge for a ploughman's lunch.  Then carried on with a mid-afternoon stop for tea at a cafe, and headed on down to the coast.  We walked west along the beach for about a mile before reaching our hotel called the Seaside Boarding House. Along the way we saw a parasailor gliding back and forth along the top of the cliff. 

Our hotel is the white building on the centre atop the cliff in the photo below.

It has a lovely view of the sea, and a constant breeze blowing. We are here for two nights before taking the train back to London on Saturday.

items.title: England 2023 - Day 6
items.summary: This morning we were driven to West Milton to begin our walk - there was a choice of 9.5 or 6 miles and we opted for 6! Generally less strenuous terrain today. It began with a long section along the edge of a field -…
items.content_html:
This morning we were driven to West Milton to begin our walk - there was a choice of 9.5 or 6 miles and we opted for 6!  Generally less strenuous terrain today.

It began with a long section along the edge of a field - fortunately we did not have to climb the slope.

 

About an hour's walk brought us to Mangerton Mill.  There is a nice little cafe there, so we stopped and had a second coffee and snack.

We carried on to Loders, another lovely little village with a beautiful church.  It was locked so we weren't able to go in, but a nice spot to rest. 

So many idyllic scenes along the way...

We arrived at our hotel in Bridport around 12:30.  It was built in 1798 as a school for dissenting ministers (those who refused to conform to the Church of England).  

I had a nap, and then we headed out to walk to the ocean - a town called West Bay.  About a 40 minute walk to the beach, and a spectacular cliff. 

West Bay is pretty, but quite touristy - I can imagine that it would be packed out in the summer!  There is a caravan park that you walk throught to get there - I guess you can rent a caravan (aka mobile home/trailor) for a week or two.  They are all pretty much identical - not my idea of fun when there are so many interesting places to visit here - but to each their own!

Rather than end with a photo of caravans, will leave you with this photo from earlier today....

items.title: England 2023 - Day 5
items.summary: After a full English breakfast at the hotel this morning, we struck out on our walk - 9.5 miles to go today! Lots of variety in the terrain - fields, narrow paths, tree-lined lanes. Fortunately almost none of the path is along roads because they…
items.content_html:
After a full English breakfast at the hotel this morning, we struck out on our walk - 9.5 miles to go today!  Lots of variety in the terrain - fields, narrow paths, tree-lined lanes.  Fortunately almost none of the path is along roads because they are really narrow and cars drive at breakneck speeds along them.

 

We came to an old church surrounded by an even older gravyard.

Some graves were not so old - like this heartbreaking one below - note the stone teddy bear.

Leaving the church we moved on through the tiny village of Netherbury.

Lots of sheep along the way - they don't seem to mind walkers - I guess they are used to seeing a lot of them!

We made it to Mapperton House by about 1pm - 6 miles in.  This is a manor house started in 16th century and is the family seat of the 11th Earl of Sandwich.  In honour of that we had sandwiches for lunch followed by a cream tea.  We were pretty hungry after the 6 mile walk to get there.

Afterwards we toured the gardens behind the house.

Then we headed back to Beaminster - a further 3 miles, for a total of 9.5 miles or 25,000 steps today - a full day!  

So many beautiful views like this one along the way - it's hard to choose where to point the camera.  

Tomorrow we head to Bridport, a town that is closer to the Dorset Coast.  There is a choice between walking 9.5 miles or 5.5 miles - right now we are thinking 5.5 miles!

items.title: England 2023 - Day 4
items.summary: This morning we packed up and headed for Waterloo Rail Station to catch our 9:20 train to Crewkerne. It was about 2.5 hour trip to get there - a very comfortable ride. A taxi was waiting for us at Crewkerne to take us to Beaminster,…
items.content_html:
This morning we packed up and headed for Waterloo Rail Station to catch our 9:20 train to Crewkerne.  It was about 2.5 hour trip to get there - a very comfortable ride.  

A taxi was waiting for us at Crewkerne to take us to Beaminster, our hotel for tonight. 

We had lunch there and then set out on today's walk, a six mile one to Gerrard's Hill.  The tour company we used provides both a map and very detailed instructions which is really helpful, otherwise it is pretty easy to get lost.   Here's a sample...

The town is pretty - filled with stone houses, climbing roses, and narrow streets.

After leaving the town, the route was a combination of country roads, laneways, and footpaths through farmer's fields.  Lots of cows and sheep, and we startled a deer in a wooded area.  

We walked through the tiny village of Stoke Abbot - it reminds me of the Cotswolds where it feels like it could be sometime in the 1800s.

The village church dates from the 12th century.

From there the route takes you up to the top of Gerrard's Hill with great views of the surrounding countryside.

The walk was six miles long and took us about 3.5 hours.  There were a few rough areas to go through...

And some narrow paths...

Overall a beautiful walk and we certainly worked up an appetite for supper.  Tomorrow there is a longer walk planned - out and back from this hotel, and then Wednesday we walk to our next hotel.  We're thankful that the heat wave has passed - walking this in 30 degree weather wouldn't be nearly as enjoyeable!

items.title: England 2023- Day 3
items.summary: This morning we took the tube to Bermondsey station, on the south side of the Thames. From there it was a short walk to Bermondsey Gospel Hall. A very friendly group there with lots of kids. They get lots of visitors as it is the…
items.content_html:
This morning we took the tube to Bermondsey station, on the south side of the Thames.  From there it was a short walk to Bermondsey Gospel Hall.  

A very friendly group there with lots of kids.  They get lots of visitors as it is the only gospel hall in central London.  After the breaking of bread, there was a short message to the kids, and then a ministry message.

We finished around 12:30 and walked back to the tube station, and headed for Liberty London, a department store with a large fabric section which Janet wanted to scout out for when we are back in London next week.  We had lunch in the cafe there, and then checked out the store.  The store was established in 1875 and the current store built in 1924 using timbers from two 19th century three-decker battle ships - the HMS Impregnable and the HMS Hindostan.  

We headed back to our airbnb around 3pm, picking up some cinnamon buns on the way.  After a nap and cinnamon buns and coffee, we were sufficiently fortified to head out to Keningston Park.  This is a large park surrounding Kensington Palace - it was packed with people this evening enjoying cooler weather.

Queen Victoria was born and raised in Kensington Palace.  When she became Queen she moved to Buckingham Palace and monarchs since then have lived at Buckingham Palace.

We walked up a street lined with embassies, and then headed home along Holland Park Road.

Tomorrow we take the train from Waterloo Station to Crewkerne in the Dorset Coast area, to begin the walking tour.

items.title: England 2023 - Day 2
items.summary: A quiet day today catching up with the time change. It's really warm here again today - heading up to 32. The heat wave is supposed to end by Monday. We didn't do much this am, had an early lunch and then took the subway…
items.content_html:
A quiet day today catching up with the time change.  It's really warm here again today - heading up to 32.  The heat wave is supposed to end by Monday.  We didn't do much this am, had an early lunch and then took the subway over to Marks & Spencer on Kensington High Street.  We picked up supper from the M&S food hall, and I walked back to our airbnb through Holland Park - here are a few photos from along the way...

After getting home I had my second nap of the day :).  Janet stayed longer at M&S and took the subway back.  Supper here, then coffee on the balcony watching the sun go down.  

Tomorrow we plan to go to Bermondsey Gospel Hall for the breaking of bread - it is about a 30-40 minute subway ride.  With an 11 am start time for the meeting, we won't need to be in a hurry tomorrow morning!

items.title: England 2023 - Day 1
items.summary: Our England trip has begun! We took an Uber to the Ottawa Airport for our 7pm flight to Toronto. A short wait there for the overnight flight to London. Didn't feel like we got much sleep but happy to be safely in London. Customs was…
items.content_html:
Our England trip has begun!  We took an Uber to the Ottawa Airport for our 7pm flight to Toronto.  A short wait there for the overnight flight to London.  Didn't feel like we got much sleep but happy to be safely in London.  Customs was a breeze - there is a separate line for UK, US, Canadians, Australians etc and then a much longer one for everyone else - I guess it's a benefit of being a former colony...

We walked through to train area of the terminal and took the Elizabeth Line subway towards town.  This is a new line that just opened last year, and the trains are air conditioned!  Very pleased that our TD Visa card now works to tap and go on the tube - no need to buy tickets or cards, and no worrying about if you have enough money on the card for the rides for the day.

Our Airbnb host was very accommodating and had our place ready by noon instead of the usual 3pm check in time.  It is in the Kensington area of London along Holland Park Avenue, only about 200 metress from the subway.  Holland Park is lined with large trees and lots of cafes, bakeries, a small Tesco's, and even a book store!  The apartment is really nice with big windows, new cupboards and bathroom and a cute balcony.

 

We stowed our bags and went out for a piece of pizza and back to airbnb for a nap - Janet slept but I ended up trying to figure out how to switch our phones to UK sim cards and plans...

We headed out to Tesco's around 6:30 and picked up some ready made meals we could heat in the microwave.

In the evening we had our coffee out on the balcony and watched the light fade.

Looking forward to sleeping horizontally tonight!

items.title: USA Road Trip - Post #30
items.summary: For the final post of this series I thought I would share a bit of our daily routine on the trip as well as some reflections. First, our daily routine... Accommodation - we used hotels.com to book our hotel each night. We would generally book…
items.content_html:
For the final post of this series I thought I would share a bit of our daily routine on the trip as well as some reflections.

First, our daily routine...

Accommodation - we used hotels.com to book our hotel each night.  We would generally book the night before - since we were in off season, we didn't have any issues.  An exception to this was for Yosemite and the Grand Canyon - we booked those places a few nights ahead.  Hotels.com makes it easy to see all the hotels in a given area and the ratings.  We found their ratings were pretty accurate - anything below an 8/10 wasn't the greatest.  Mostly we stayed at Fairfield (by Marriott) and Holiday Inn Express.  The Victorian Inn in Ferndale, Rush Creek Lodge in Yosemite, Bright Angel Lodge in the Grand Canyon were all unique hotel experiences (and also more expensive!).  Hotels.com also gives you a free night for every 10 stays, so we made use of that.

Food...we stayed mostly in hotels that offered a free breakfast.  Many of them had real oatmeal, bacon and eggs, toast/bagels, juice, yogurt etc.  Before leaving the hotel I would fill up our two thermoses with tea from the breakfast area, and refill our water bottles.  For lunch we would usually stop at a rest area or some pretty spot if we could find one and have bread and cheese, along with our tea and some chocolate.  We stored cheese etc in our Yeti cooler.  It kept things quite cold - I would change the ice every day if it was warm and every other day when colder out.

This meant we didn't have to find a place to buy lunch every day, and with a large breakfast we didn't need a big lunch.  For supper we would usually eat out somewhere.  A couple of times we found a Panera Bread and had soup and a sandwich.

Driving in the van... we found that 4-5 hours of driving a day was a good amount.  We could do the occasional long day of 7-9 hours, but we tried not to do too many of those in a row. I would usually drive in the morning.  After lunch Janet would drive while I had a nap.  We used google maps on my phone for navigation and it worked well.  Occasionally we would override google's choice of route if we wanted something more scenic.   Even though it was just two of us, having the van was so much more comfortable than a car.  A long wheel base means a smoother ride, you sit up a bit higher, and we had plenty of room for stuff we bought along the way.  The Odessey also has a very large gas tank of 21 gallons.  At optimal highway driving, we could go more than 1000 km on one tank, although after our near miss in northern Michigan, we always looked to keep the gas gauge well above a quarter full!  We listened to audiobooks (Lord of the Rings narrated by Andy Serkus - we made it through books 1 and 2 and partway into book 3) for quite a bit of the way (unless it was a really scenic section like Glacier National Park).

One advantage of the interstate system are the rest areas along these roads.  They are generally well maintained and located in pretty spots along the road, and spaced out every 30-40 miles or so.

 I also brought a small Ryobi cordless vaccum to keep the van clean.  

It sounds a bit silly, but when you spending that much time in the van, climbing into a relatively clean vehicle each morning is so much more pleasant!

Some overall reflections:

  • the sheer size of North America - especially the mid-west.  When you drive for days and still are a long way from the coast, the distance sinks in a bit more
  • the variety of landscapes - we expected some parts to be flat and somewhat boring, but each part of the country has its own charm.  There were some surprises along the way - the scenery from Glacier National Park to Kalispell, the mountain pass to get into Yosemite, the drive from Kayenta to Moab, and the mountain passes coming into Denver from the west. 
  • a flexible schedule allowed for unexpected sightseeing - quite a number of times we happened upon areas that were worth exploring and so we stopped and checked them out - the Theodore Roosevelt National Park, the town of Ferndale, the Humbolt Redwoods State Park in Northern California, the town square in Washington Illinois.  I suppose if we had done more research in advance these wouldn't have been surprises.  Still, it was nice to have the flexibility to stop and enjoy these places.  
  • being able to get off the Interstate and use other roads makes for more interesting driving.  And many of these secondary highways are quite good and have a speed limit of 65 mph so you can still make good time.  We enjoyed these roads in Montana, the Oregon Coast, the trip to Yosemite, and heading north from Kayenta.
  • meeting up with family, friends and fellow-believers.  Seeing where Mitch lives in California and spending time with him, dinner with Carolyn and Steve, visiting with Joe and Penny Clark in Montana, and being with the believers in Spring Creek - these were all highlights of our trip.  

Here is an overall map of our trip...

Well, that concludes this blog series - thanks for reading!!

items.title: USA Road Trip - Post #29
items.summary: Very thankful to be home again after 28 days and 12,537 km of travel! God is good. The Odessey held up well, and we were blessed with good weather and safe travelling. We left our hotel in Port Huron at 7am this morning while it…
items.content_html:
Very thankful to be home again after 28 days and 12,537 km of travel!  God is good.  The Odessey held up well, and we were blessed with good weather and safe travelling.

We left our hotel in Port Huron at 7am this morning while it was still dark.  Happy to see no lineup at customs.

A friendly customs officer asked us how the trip went, and then waved us on through.  On to the 402 through to the 401 and to Ottawa, with just a couple of quick stops.  It looks like the fall colors are at their peak here.

We arrived home around 3pm - so nice to see familiar territory.  Everything is in good shape at 874 Clearcrest -  Amy took good care of the house while we were gone, even raking the leaves!  

She had us over for a delicious supper - really nice way to ease back into home life again!

I'm planning one more post tomorrow to wrap up this series - a little bit about our daily routine on the trip, and some overall reflections.
